DOC.TEXT: The government said its chief barometer of future economic activity edged up 0.1 percent in November, a tiny increase seen by many analysts as evidence that growth in 1990 will be modest at best. The Commerce Department said Friday the small rise in its Index of Leading Economic Indicators followed a revised 0.3 percent decline in October. For most of the year, the leading index has been flashing signals that the U.S. economy was headed for a rather dramatic slowdown in growth and analysts said the weak November showing did not change that picture.

Workers feel increasingly insecure at their jobs and are worried about layoffs in 1990, an informal call-in survey sponsored by a job-counseling company found. About 600 of the 1,100 people who participated in the national call-in were employed, and nearly half of that number, 44 percent, felt 1990 would bring significant changes for them in the workplace, the firm, Challenger, Gray & Christmas, said Friday. The survey is not scientific because it was not a random sampling of the population.

United Airlines, Trans World Airlines and Eastern Airlines said they were considering new surcharges on tickets to help cover the skyrocketing cost of jet fuel. Other airlines also may be weighing the measure, which if imposed would be the first special fuel surcharge by the airlines since the 1970s oil crisis. A fuel surcharge likely would be figured into fares rather than charged separately, analysts suggested Friday. They speculated the airlines might charge around $3 per ticket.

Energy futures prices surged as a late rally boosted heating oil to a six-year high on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Heating oil for delivery in January, which had declined Thursday after a two-week rise, jumped 5.47 cents Friday to finish at $1.0187, helped by a wave of frenzied buying in the final 30 minutes of trading. The advances followed a string of sharp gains in recent weeks due to severe cold and declining inventories.

Prices received by farmers for raw products averaged a record high in 1989, eclipsing the old 12-month mark set five years ago, according to preliminary figures from the Agriculture Department. Prices farmers got for raw products rose 0.7 percent from November to December, leaving the monthly average 2.1 percent above the level of December 1988, the department's Agricultural Statistics Board said Friday.

The once-raucous takeover business ended the 1980s subdued and humbled as the value of corporate acquisitions plunged more than 60 percent in the fourth quarter from the stratospheric levels of a year earlier. There were 935 acquisitions valued at $72.2 billion announced during the last quarter of 1989, Securities Data Corp., a financial research firm, said Friday. A year earlier, when the merger business reached its zenith with the record $24.53 billion buyout of RJR Nabisco Inc., there were two fewer deals, 933, but the acquisitions totaled a record $183.1 billion.

Heck's Inc., unable to turn a profit despite emerging from federal bankruptcy court protection, said it would sell its retail operations, including 55 discount stores in six states, to New York-based Jordache Enterprises Inc. Faced with mounting debts that totaled $9 million since February, Heck's essentially decided to give away its retailers to a subsidiary of Jordache which in return will assume the chain's debts and longterm obligations, Heck's said Friday.

The Australian brewing interests of Bond Corp. Holdings Ltd. were placed in receivership by a state Supreme Court after National Australia Bank Ltd., a major lender, requested the action. The move cast further doubt on the future of the G. Heileman Brewing Co., based in La Crosse, Wis. Alan Bond, who controls Bond Corp. Holdings, purchased Heileman in 1987 for about $1.3 billion.

Campbell Soup Co. said it has completed its search for a new chief executive officer but will not disclose its choice until after New Year's. Campbell Chairman Robert J. Vlasic said Friday the board of directors' first choice has accepted an offer to succeed R. Gordon McGovern, who retired in November as president and chief executive officer of the food-products company. Three members of the Campbell family, which controls about 59 percent of the company's 129.6 million outstanding common shares, said Thursday they would sell their 17 percent stake and urge a sale of the entire company.

The stock market closed out a decade of dramatic gains with a broad advance Friday. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 20.90 to 2,753.20, extending its gain for the week to 41.81 points. The dollar closed higher in light dealings. Bond prices fell in light trading. Energy futures surged, orange juice futures rose dramatically, precious metals advanced, grains and soybeans were mixed, and livestock and meat futures were mixed.
